what: A companion R package for The Research Quality Evaluation (RESQUE) Framework

what: How to create an individual profile (html file):
title: A companion R package for The Research Quality Evaluation (RESQUE) Framework
text: need Quarto installed system.
code: library(quarto) library(RESQUER)  # The rendered html file is created in the same folder as the input json file. # `outfile` also contains the path to the rendered file json_path = "resque_123456.json" outfile <- render_profile(json_path)

title: A companion R package for The Research Quality Evaluation (RESQUE) Framework
text: $impact_pubs subset indicators: contains publications eligible impact table (.e., papers sufficient indicator information papers manual processing requested) $rigor_pubs subset $impact_pubs: contains publications eligible rigor score descriptives (.e., papers sufficient indicator information)

what: Radar Chart for Relative Rigor Score — RRS_radarchart
title: Radar Chart for Relative Rigor Score — RRS_radarchart
text: function generates radar chart visualizes rigor profile given applicant's data.

title: Radar Chart for Relative Rigor Score — RRS_radarchart
code: RRS_radarchart(   RRS,   title = "",   overall_score = FALSE,   minimal = FALSE,   show.legend = TRUE,   show.n_pub = TRUE,   base_size = 14 )

title: Radar Chart for Relative Rigor Score — RRS_radarchart
text: RRS output compute_RRS function. title main title plot. overall_score Show overall score plot? minimal TRUE, simple chart without legends drawn show.legend Show legend right? show.n_pub Show number publication chart based? base_size Base font size

title: Radar Chart for Relative Rigor Score — RRS_radarchart
text: radar chart visualizing rigor profile applicant, showing distribution scores across different dimensions.

title: Radar Chart for Relative Rigor Score — RRS_radarchart
code: radar_dat <- data.frame(   dimension = c("Open Data", "Open Materials", "Preregistration",     "Reproducible Code \n& Verification", "Theorizing \n& Formal Modeling"),   max_points = rep(10, 5),   rel_score=c(0.5, 0.3, 0.1, 0.6, 0.2),   xstart = 0:4,   xend = 1:5,   xmid=0:4 + 0.5 ) RRS <- list(radar_dat=radar_dat, overall_score=0.5, n_papers=4) RRS_radarchart(RRS)

what: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
title: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
text: function searches text URLs, extracts , checks whether resolve valid websites. handles broken URLs (connection errors, HTTP errors) URLs technically resolve lead "found" pages.

title: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
text: text character string containing potential URLs checked. tout timeout, defaults 5 seconds

title: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
text: data frame following columns: url extracted URLs text. valid Logical value indicating whether URL valid. status_code HTTP status code returned (available). error Error message URL invalid, NA otherwise.

title: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
text: function first extracts URLs input text using regular expressions, cleans removing trailing punctuation might incorrectly included extraction. URL, attempts HTTP request checks status code page content determine validity. URLs considered invalid : connection fails return HTTP error codes (4xx, 5xx) return 2xx 3xx status code page content suggests "found" page

title: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
text: function requires 'httr' 'stringr' packages attempt install present.

title: Check URLs in Text for Validity — check_urls
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ text <- "Check our website at https://example.com and https://invalid-url-example.xyz" results <- check_urls(text) print(results)  # Example with multiple URLs, some valid and some invalid text2 <- "We deliver open data at https://osf.io/f5zjr/; more material is found at           https://osf.io/f5zjl/ and https://osf.oi/asdf." results2 <- check_urls(text2) print(results2) } # }

title: Four layered circles — circle_layer
text: TODO: Provide color ramp breakpoints parameters

title: Four layered circles — circle_layer
code: circle_layer(   value,   colors,   outer_width = 60,   weights = c(1, 1, 1, 1),   sharp_boundaries = FALSE )

title: Four layered circles — circle_layer
text: value value 0 1 (transformed %) colors vector four colors, innermost outermost color outer_width Circle radius pixels. weights vector 4 numbers specifying relative weight layer. weights normalized percentages automatically. Default c(1, 1, 1, 1) gives equal 25% spacing. sharp_boundaries Whether create sharp color transitions (TRUE) smooth blends (FALSE)

what: Display a barchart with CRediT roles — credit_barchart
title: Display a barchart with CRediT roles — credit_barchart
text: Display barchart CRediT roles

title: Display a barchart with CRediT roles — credit_barchart
Display a barchart with CRediT roles — credit_barchart
text: credit_dat raw data format applicant()$credit field. data frame two relevant columns: Role (CRediT role) Degree (one "Lead", "Equal", "Support", "NoRole", "applicable"). Roles can appear multiple times (e.g., multiple papers) aggregated plot. ordered FALSE, keep alphabetical order. TRUE, sort strongest contribution.

title: Display a barchart with CRediT roles — credit_barchart
code: credit_dat <- data.frame(   Role = rep(c("Conceptualization", "Data Curation", "Formal Analysis",     "Funding Acquisition", "Investigation", "Methodology",     "Project Administration", "Resources", "Software", "Supervision",     "Validation", "Visualization", "Writing: Original draft",     "Writing: Review & Editing"), 10),   Degree = sample(c("Lead", "Equal", "Support", "NoRole", "not applicable"),     prob = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.3, 0.1), size=140, replace=TRUE) ) credit_barchart(credit_dat)  credit_barchart(credit_dat, ordered=TRUE)

what: Create a Horizontal Bar Chart in HTML — horizontal_bar_chart
title: Create a Horizontal Bar Chart in HTML — horizontal_bar_chart
text: Generates HTML snippet representing horizontal bar chart. bar's length proportional corresponding value relative maximum value, bar filled specified color. Optionally, labels can placed bars, x-axis displaying scale can shown.

title: Create a Horizontal Bar Chart in HTML — horizontal_bar_chart
code: horizontal_bar_chart(   values,   colors,   max_value = 10,   width = 140,   height = 60,   labels = NULL,   show_x_label = TRUE )

title: Create a Horizontal Bar Chart in HTML — horizontal_bar_chart
text: values numeric vector values representing lengths bars. colors character vector colors (valid CSS format) bar. Must length values. max_value numeric scalar indicating maximum value scaling bars. element values exceeds max_value, warning issued max_value updated maximum value found. Defaults 10. width integer specifying overall width (pixels) chart container. Defaults 140. height integer specifying overall height (pixels) chart container. Defaults 60. labels optional character vector labels display top bar. provided, length must match values. Defaults NULL. show_x_label Logical indicating whether display x-axis labels (showing 0 max_value) bars. Defaults TRUE.

title: Create a Horizontal Bar Chart in HTML — horizontal_bar_chart
text: character string containing HTML code renders horizontal bar chart.

title: Create a Horizontal Bar Chart in HTML — horizontal_bar_chart
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # Example with labels and custom colors:   values <- c(3, 7, 5)   colors <- c("#FF5733", "#33FF57", "#3357FF")   labels <- c("Low", "Medium", "High")   html_chart <- horizontal_bar_chart(values, colors, max_value = 10,                                      width = 140, height = 60,                                      labels = labels, show_x_label = TRUE)   cat(html_chart) } # }
